Parents/guardians, the Primary School dismissal schedules are a little different this year. Please view the image below for details.

"Important to Know:

--Please use the bus loop for afternoon dismissal for all parent-pickup students.
--Pull up in the bus loop to the front of the Primary School and remain in your car, while a member of the faculty and staff assists you in picking up your student.
--Please only come at your student’s designated time
By coming at an earlier time your student will still be receiving instruction in the classroom and will not be prepared for dismissal.
--If you are picking up multiple students in different grade levels, we ask you to arrive at the youngest student’s grade level time, and you can pick up all your students then."

"It is very important to remember that children look to adults for guidance on how to react to stressful events. Acknowledging some level of concern, without panicking, is appropriate and can result in taking the necessary actions that reduce the risk of illness. Teaching children positive preventive measures, talking with them about their fears, and giving them a sense of some control over their risk of infection can help reduce anxiety. This is also a tremendous opportunity for adults to model for children problem-solving, flexibility, and compassion as we all work through adjusting daily schedules, balancing work and other activities, getting creative about how we spend time, processing new information from authorities, and connecting and supporting friends and family members in new ways. The following tips can help..."

(From the National Association of School Psychologists)

For the past several months, we’ve been adhering to guidelines coming from the CDC, our state capitol, and
directives coming directly from the Governor’s Office in the form of Executive Orders.

Quite often, the timing of these orders has been woefully delayed.

The plans for our graduation ceremony have been well thought out, planned, problem-solved and implemented. Contracts have been signed and filming has already begun. It will be a culmination of events that have led us to this point and it will be lasting.

The 150 person limit does us no good and it is too little too late.

The Class of 2020 should graduate as a unified, cohesive class in one virtual ceremony to be aired on June 27th.

Because of this, our plan remains as is.

The 4th graders were just able to meet with Terry Stark, the Mayor of Oxford, on Zoom. They asked some excellent questions. 8. What is the hardest part of your job?
9. What was a challenge you had to face as the mayor?
10. Who helps you with running the village?
11. Do you want to run for reelection?
12. How many years are your terms?

post_text:
Primary AND Middle School students and families, there is still time to get your projects ready for the Greatest Show and Tell Expo happening Thursday, March 5!

It could be almost anything: crafts, games, inventions, food/cooking, robots, woodworking, structures, paintings, drawings, sculpture, comics, knitting, and the list goes on and on.

Your exhibit information is due TOMORROW (Monday, February 24). Please send in names, grades, project description, and project size (how much space will you need to display your project? Does it need a desk, or a table, or floor space?).

Each student taking part in this event must be accompanied by an adult.

We can't wait to see what you've made!
